Graphical abstract For the selective hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of erythritol to butanediols, a carbon-supported Cu catalyst (Cu/C) with small copper particles (diameter of 14.9 nm) at high metal loading (66.9 wt%) was prepared using a weakly acidic cation-exchange resin as the carbon support precursor. Compared with the activated carbon-supported Cu catalyst prepared by the impregnation method, Cu/C showed high activity, high butanediol selectivity, and high sintering resistance. The effects of reaction temperature, reaction time, and initial hydrogen pressure on erythritol conversion and butanediol selectivity were also studied. The highest butanediol yield of 18.3 C-mol% at a butanediol selectivity of 54 C-mol% was realized over the Cu/C catalyst at 180 °C and 1.8 MPa H2 for 240 h. Moreover, the HDO of erythritol to butanediols over Cu/C proceeded mainly via 1,2,4-butanetriol. Vicinal diols such as 1,2-butanediol and 2,3-butanediol were favorably formed over the Cu surface because the substrates were adsorbed on Cu via the two vicinal OH groups and these OH groups did not participate in the HDO reactions. Abbreviations HDO hydrodeoxygenation Cu/C carbon-supported Cu catalyst TEM transmission electron microscopy AC activated carbon SEM scanning electron microscopy BET Brunauer-Emmett-Teller XRD X-ray powder diffraction FID flame ionization detector GC gas chromatograph MS mass spectrometer TOF turnover frequency Keywords Erythritol Hydrodeoxygenation Carbon supported Cu catalyst Biomass-derived polyol Butanediols 1 Introduction Utilizing renewable biomass as an alternative to petrochemicals is widely considered an effective strategy to address global warming issues and the depletion of fossil fuels [1–3]. Biomass is a complex mixture of polymers, including cellulose, hemicellulose, and lignin. Therefore, degradation and fragmentation of biomass are required to obtain the raw materials of petrochemical alternatives. Polyols, such as glycerol, erythritol, xylitol, and sorbitol, are promising biomass-derived raw materials of value-added chemicals because they can be produced from cheap materials without affecting food supplies or land use [4,5]. Erythritol (meso-1,2,3,4-butanetetraol; C4H6(OH)4) is a major biomass-derived polyol produced by fermentative processes with glucose and sucrose derived from starch [6]. It can be used as a raw material for the production of butanediols, tetrahydrofuran, and butane dienes [6–10]. Among the products obtained from erythritol, butanediols are one of the valuable chemicals widely used as building blocks in the chemical industry, intermediates in the pharmaceutical industry, and monomers in polymer production [11]. Because erythritol has a high oxygen content (O/C = 1), the removal of oxygen without CC bond cleavage is required to obtain these valuable chemicals from erythritol. Hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) and hydrogenolysis have been intensively studied for the selective removal of oxygen from polyols [12–26]. HDO reactions are generally conducted in aqueous solutions under pressurized hydrogen atmospheres with metal catalysts [12,13]. Although the use of erythritol as a raw material of valuable chemicals has attracted increasing attention, reports on the conversion of erythritol to butanediols are scarce compared with other polyols such as sorbitol [12–14] and glycerol [15,16]. Similar to HDO of other polyols, noble metal catalysts, including Rh, Ru, Re, Pd, Ir, and their alloys, have been studied for the HDO of erythritol to obtain value-added butanediols such as 1,2-butanediol, 1,3-butanediol, 2,3-butanediol and 1,4-butanediol [10,13–26]. An oxophilic promoter (Re, Mo, or W) can enhance the catalytic performance of reducible noble metal (Ir, Rh, or Ru) based catalysts for polyol HDO [17,20,21]. The dehydration-hydrogenation mechanism and the three-step mechanism composed of dehydrogenation, dehydration, and hydrogenation [16,26] are generally reported as the HDO reaction mechanism to obtain 1,2-butanediol, 2,3-butanediol and 1,3-butanediol, where solid acid sites of the catalyst support catalyze dehydration reaction. The highest 1,2-butanediol yield was achieved by using ReO x -Pd/CeO2 catalyst and 1,4-dioxiane solvent at 433 K under 8 MPa H2 [10]. Additionally, the selective production of 1,3-butanediols and 1,4-butanediol via 1,4-anhydroerythritol have recently been reported over Rhenium containing catalysts [22–25]. However, because of the high price and limited availability of these noble metals, non-noble metal catalysts are attractive for practical applications. Cu is one of the most promising candidates in polyol HDO because of its high selectivity to CO bond cleavage [27,28], high earth abundance, and low price [29,30]. Early studies on erythritol HDO over Cu catalysts were conducted over Raney Cu catalysts under 4 MPa of hydrogen at temperatures over 500 K, and 1,2-butanediol was obtained as the main HDO product with 48 % selectivity [26,31]. Recently, Jin et al. reported that the Cu/CaO-Al2O3 catalyst achieved 85 % erythritol conversion with 39 % 1,2-butanediol selectivity at 230 °C under 2.8 MPa H2 [12]. It is commonly accepted that the performance of metal catalysts is affected by the catalyst support. Metal oxide supports, such as Al2O3 and SiO2, are generally selected as the support of metal catalysts because small metal particles can be loaded because of their high surface area and solid acid sites. However, in HDO reactions, the solid acid sites can cause side reactions, such as oligomerization and degradation, such as retro-aldol condensation [32–35]. The degradation of erythritol produces undesired by-products, including short-chain polyols and gas products (such as CO2 and CH4), which decreases the selectivity and yield of the desired C4 products. Therefore, to suppress these side reactions, inert supports with no active site are preferred. Carbon is one of the most intensively studied support because of its inertness, large surface area, and mechanical resistance [36]. However, carbon-supported copper catalysts prepared by conventional impregnation methods have difficulty stabilizing small Cu particles because of the weak interaction between the metal and the carbon support and the low Hüttig temperature (approximately 407 K) of Cu. Therefore, rapid deactivation was observed in the erythritol conversion over an activated carbon-supported Cu catalyst at ∼500 K due to the sintering of Cu particles [31]. Moreover, the conventional impregnation method cannot achieve high Cu particle dispersion, especially under high metal loading, resulting in low catalytic activity. Due to the low activity of conventionally prepared carbon-supported copper catalysts, high reaction temperatures (>200 °C) are required for erythritol HDO, causing a decrease in the selectivity for HDO products [28]. High hydrogen pressures (>2 MPa) can suppress side reactions while incurring extra cost because of the handling of pressurized hydrogen. Thus, to realize selective HDO of erythritol at low temperatures and low hydrogen pressures, Cu catalysts are required to possess the following properties: inert support, high Cu dispersion with high metal loading, and high sintering resistance. To synthesize a promising carbon-supported Cu catalyst for erythritol HDO, we focused on the novel carbon-supported metal catalysts prepared using ion-exchange resin [37–42]. This catalyst preparation procedure consists of two steps: ion exchange and carbonization. First, in the ion-exchange step, metal ions are loaded on the ion-exchange resin by ion exchange in a basic solution to prepare the metal-loaded resin. Next, in the carbonization step, the metal-loaded resin is carbonized at 500 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere, where the ion-exchange resin is pyrolyzed to carbon with concomitant reduction of the metal ion to metal particles. Pt, Pd, Ni, and Pt-Ni alloy catalysts with high metal dispersion (particle size of 2.3–3.8 nm observed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM)) and high metal loading (>10 wt%) were prepared by this method in our previous studies [39,40]. Because the ion-exchange resin can be ionized in a basic solution, the formation of stable metal ions in the solution is required. As Cu forms Cu(NH3)2+ cations in concentrated ammonia solutions, similar to Pt and Ni, this preparation method can be applied to prepare carbon-supported Cu catalysts [41]. In the present work, a carbon-supported Cu catalyst (Cu/C) was prepared by the ion exchange of Cu ions onto a weakly acidic cation-exchange resin, followed by carbonization. The prepared catalyst was applied to the HDO of erythritol to butanediols under mild reaction conditions (T ≤ 180 °C, p H2 ≤ 1.8 MPa). In addition, the effects of reaction temperature, reaction time, and hydrogen pressure on erythritol HDO over the prepared Cu/C were investigated to elucidate the reaction mechanism of erythritol HDO over the prepared Cu/C. 2 Experiment 2.1 Catalyst preparation The preparation method of Cu/C catalysts was modified from the method described in previous reports [37–40]. The weakly acidic cation-exchange resin, WK-11 (Mitsubishi Chemical, Japan; total exchange capacity: 4.3 mEq/g-resin; mean particle size: 620 μm), contain methacrylic acid moieties as ion-exchange sites and was used as the carbon source, while Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (98 % pure; FUJIFILM Wako Pure Chemical Ltd., Japan) was used as the Cu precursor. First, the Cu-loaded resin was prepared by ion exchange; 5 g of WK-11 was added to 100 mL of distilled water, and then 100 mL of Cu(NO3)2·solution (0.4 mol/L) was added dropwise to the resin solution at room temperature with stirring. The pH of the solution was adjusted to 8.8 using an aqueous ammonia solution (28 wt%; FUJIFILM Wako Pure Chemical Ltd., Japan), and the time the pH reached 8.8 was taken as the starting time of ion exchange. The pH value was adjusted to 8.8 at 2 h and 4 h after the commencement of ion exchange. After 24 h of ion exchange, the Cu-loaded resin was collected by filtration and dried at room temperature overnight. The Cu/C catalysts were obtained by treating the Cu-loaded resin at 500 °C for 30 min in a N2 atmosphere. For comparison, an activated carbon (AC) supported Cu catalyst (Cu/AC), an amorphous silica supported Cu catalyst (Cu/SiO2), and commercial Cu chromite (Sigma-Aldrich, Japan) were used. Cu/AC and Cu/SiO2 were prepared by an impregnation method using a commercial AC (Norit® RX3 EXTRA, Sigma-Aldrich Japan) and an amorphous SiO2 (JRC-SIO12) provided by Catalysis Society of Japan as the carbon support. The catalyst support was ground into powders with diameters ranging from 300 to 850 μm and then dried overnight in an oven at 110 °C. A predetermined amount of the aqueous Cu(NO3)2 solution was added dropwise to the dried support. The solvent remaining in the sample was removed at 60 °C and 15 kPa for 1 h, and then, the sample was further dried at 110 °C in the oven overnight. The dried sample was finally calcined under a N2 atmosphere at 500 °C for 30 min. Cu chromite was calcined in N2 stream at 500 °C for 30 min before characterization and catalyst test. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The amount of Cu metal loaded onto carbon was estimated using a thermogravimetric analyzer (Thermo plus Evo2 TG8120, Rigaku Corp., Japan). The sample was heated to 900 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min in a N2 stream, and then, the gas stream was changed to air to combust the carbon support. The Cu weight in the sample was calculated assuming that the carbon supports were completely combusted and CuO was formed as ash. The morphology of the catalysts was observed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM; VE-9800, Keyence Corp., Japan) at 8 kV. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of the catalysts was estimated from the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms obtained at −196 °C using a high-precision volumetric gas adsorption analyzer (BELSORP-mini, MicrotracBEL Corp., Japan) The Cu particle size and surface area were estimated by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD; MiniFlex 600, Rigaku Corp., Japan), TEM (H-7650 Zero.A, Hitachi High-Technologies Corp., Japan), and N2O titration (BELCAT II, MicrotracBEL Corp., Japan). All samples were pretreated in 10 vol% H2 containing N2 stream at 350 °C for 1 h before XRD and TEM measurements. The XRD measurement was performed using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å), operating at 40 kV and 15 mA, with 0.02° steps and 10°/min scan speed. The diffraction peak observed at 2θ = 44.3° was employed to calculate the crystallite size (d XRD) of the Cu metal particles in the samples according to the Scherrer equation (d = kλ/βL cosθ) [43], where k is the Debye-Scherrer constant (0.9), θ is the Bragg angle, and βL is the half-width of the diffraction peak. The exposed Cu surface area was measured using N2O titration. All the samples were treated in H2 flow (50 mL/min) at 350 °C for 1 h before N2O titration at 50 °C. The Cu metal surface area was calculated from the amount of N2O consumed to oxidize the surface Cu atoms. Metal accessibility was calculated from the ratio of the exposed metal surface area measured by N2O titration (S N2O) to the geometric surface area estimated from d TEM (S TEM) assuming that the Cu particles were spherical. 2.3 Catalytic testing Erythritol hydrodeoxygenation reactions over carbon-supported Cu catalysts were carried out in a 150 mL stainless-steel batch reactor (HIRO Corp., Japan). Prior to the reaction test, the catalysts were reduced in 10 vol% of H2 containing N2 stream at 350 °C for 1 h. The reduced catalysts were ground into powder and sieved into diameters less than 100 μm. In a typical experiment, 30 g of a 15 wt% aqueous erythritol solution (98 % pure, FUJIFILM Wako Pure Chemical Industries Ltd., Japan) and a predetermined amount of catalyst were introduced into the reactor. After the remaining air was purged out with H2, the reactor was pressurized with H2 and heated to the designed reaction temperature. The time, at which the reactor reached the reaction temperature, was considered as the starting time of hydrodeoxygenation. After the desired reaction time, the reactor was quenched in an ice bath to terminate the reaction. The gaseous product was collected in a gas pack with argon and analyzed using a GC-2014 gas chromatograph equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) connected to a SHINCARBON ST column (Shinwa Chemical Industries Ltd., Japan) and flame ionization detector (FID) connected to a Porapak Q column (GL Sciences Inc., Japan). The liquid products were collected with the catalysts and separated from the catalysts by centrifugation. The liquid products were identified using a gas chromatograph (GC-2010, Shimadzu Co. Ltd., Japan) equipped with a DB-WAX capillary column (Agilent Technologies Japan Ltd.) and a mass spectrometer (Parvum 2, Shimadzu Co. Ltd., Japan), and quantified using a gas chromatograph (GC-2014, Shimadzu Co. Ltd., Japan) equipped with the same capillary column and an FID. The conversion of erythritol, product yield, selectivity, and carbon recovery were calculated on a carbon basis according to Eq.s 1–4: (1) X C – m o l % = 1 - m o l o f c a r b o n a t o m s i n u n c o n v e r t e d r e a c t a n t m o l o f c a r b o n a t o m s i n i n i t i a l r e a c t a n t × 100 % (2) Y i [ C – m o l % ] = m o l o f c a r b o n a t o m s in products i ∑ m o l o f c a r b o n a t o m s i n i n i t i a l r e a c t a n t × 100 % (3) S i [ C – m o l % ] = m o l o f c a r b o n a t o m s i n p r o d u c t s i ∑ m o l o f c a r b o n a t o m s i n p r o d u c t s × 100 % (4) C r e c o v e r y [ C – m o l % ] = m o l o f c a r b o n a t o m s r e c o v e r e d a f t e r r e a c t i o n m o l o f c a r b o n a t o m s i n i n i t i a l r e a c t a n t × 100 % where Y BuT and S BuT denote the sum of the yields and the sum of the selectivities of all the butanetriol isomers. Similarly, Y BuD and S BuD denote the sum of the yields and the sum of the selectivities of all the butanediols isomers. Y HDO indicates the sum of the yields of the HDO products, including all the butanetoriols, butanediols, butanols, and butane. The unidentified products, labelled as “Others” in following figures and tables, were components which was observed by the GC-FID but could not be identified by the GC–MS. The carbon recovery was ranged from 78 to 129 C-mol%, which could be attributed by the formation of oligomerized products and highly oxygenated products, the products clogged in the pores of the catalysts, and/or experimental error. Threitol, which is a stereoisomer of erythritol, was obtained for all HDO test of erythritol while it was considered an unconverted reactant because threitol can be converted to butanediols by HDO, similar to erythritol [16]. The turnover frequency (TOF) was estimated by using Eq (5): (5) T O F [ h - 1 ] = m o l o f t h e c o n v e r t e d r e a c t a n t m o l o f C u a t o m s o n a c c e s s i b l e s u r f a c e × R e a c t i o n t i m e The accessible Cu surface area obtained by N2O titration was used to estimate the number of Cu atoms on the accessible surface. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The metal loading, BET surface area, metal particle size, and metal surface area of the synthesized catalysts are listed in Table 1 . The prepared Cu/C catalyst was spherical with diameters of 200–600 μm (Fig. 1 ), suggesting that the shape of the initial resin was maintained during the carbonization process. The high metal loading of Cu/C (66.9 wt%) was due to the high ion-exchange capability of resin and the high Cu concentration. The prepared Cu/C showed type I isotherms, indicating that Cu/C was rich in micropores, and the BET surface area of Cu/C was 119 m2/g. As reported in our previous research, the BET surface area of the initial WK-11 resin is 5.7 m2/g [40]. The BET surface area of Cu/C was larger than that of the initial resin because structural changes of the resin occurred during the carbonization step. As shown in Fig. S1, the decomposition of functional groups on the ion-exchange resin and the generation of small molecular gases, such as CO, CO2, and H2O, proceeded at approximately 200–300 °C. In this step, ion-exchangeable functional groups were removed and therefore the acid sites of carbon support were disappeared. Moreover, the cleavage and recombination of carbon-carbon bonds on the resin with simultaneous production of tar (large aliphatic hydrocarbons and/or poly aromatic rings) proceeded at approximately 300–400 °C. The BET surface area of Cu/AC was 1250 m2/g because of the large surface area of the original AC. The crystal structure and particle size of Cu in the Cu/C and Cu/AC catalysts were investigated by XRD measurements. As shown in Fig. 2 , the diffraction peaks at 44.3, 50.4, and 74.1° were ascribed to metallic Cu (JCPDS 85–1326) [43], suggesting that Cu was successfully loaded on the carbon support in the metallic state for all catalysts. The particle size of the Cu metal in Cu/C and Cu/AC, determined from the XRD patterns (d XRD), was 13.9 and 22.7 nm, respectively. The d XRD of Cu/C was consistent with the Cu particle size observed by TEM (d TEM = 14.9 nm, Fig. 3 (a)), indicating that the Cu particle size in Cu/C was almost uniform. From the above results, we concluded that the carbon-supported Cu catalyst with a small metal particle size was successfully prepared using an ion-exchange resin as the starting material. The higher dispersion of Cu on Cu/C was possibly due to the high dispersion of the Cu precursor on the ion-exchange resin. In contrast, the XRD pattern of Cu/AC contained overlapping intense sharp peaks and small broad peaks at 44.3°, suggesting a wide particle size distribution in Cu/AC. This result was consistent with TEM observations. Cu particles with diameters ranging from 3.9–45.0 nm were observed in Cu/AC, as shown in Fig. 3(b). The wide Cu particle size distribution of the Cu/AC prepared by the impregnation method was ascribed to the severe aggregation of Cu particles due to the weak interactions between Cu and carbon during the preparation of the catalyst, even though the surface area of AC was higher than 1250 m2/g. Similarly, the sharp XRD patterns and large Cu particles with wide size distribution in TEM image (Fig. 2 and S2) were obtained for Cu/SiO2 and Cu chromite, indicating agglomeration of Cu particles during the preparation and reduction of these catalysts. The accessible Cu surface area of Cu/C estimated from N2O titration (S N2O) was smaller than the geometric Cu surface area (S TEM), indicating that the Cu particles were partially embedded in the carbon support and the entire surface of Cu particles was inaccessible to N2O molecules. The formation of Cu particles and the softening and melting of the resin occurred simultaneously during the carbonization step of the Cu/C preparation process. The Cu particles in Cu/C were confined in the carbon support, which inhibited further aggregation of the Cu particles. The metal accessibility, which represents the ratio of accessible metal surface area to the geometric area, was estimated to be 7.9 %. In contrast, a small amount of N2O was adsorbed on Cu/AC because of the wide size distribution of the Cu particles in Cu/AC. Notably, the available Cu surface area and metal loading of Cu/C were significantly higher than those of Cu/AC, indicating that the catalytic activity of Cu/C is higher than that of Cu/AC. 3.2 Catalytic activity for erythritol HDO 3.2.1 Effect of catalyst preparation methods on catalytic performance First, to compare the activity of the prepared catalysts for erythritol HDO, reaction tests were conducted at 180 °C under 1.8 MPa H2 for 24 h. The ratio of the amount of Cu and the amount of the reactant in the reactor was fixed at 0.04 gCu/gerythritol for all prepared catalysts. The erythritol conversion over Cu/C reached 3.91 C-mol% and TOF value of 4.0 h−1. The desired reaction, HDO of erythritol without CC bond cleavage, proceeded over the Cu/C catalyst to produce 1,2,4-butanetriol (1,2,4-BuT), 1,2-butanediol (1,2-BuD), 2,3-butanediol (2,3-BuD), and 1,4-butanediol (1,4-BuD), and the HDO product yield was 2.68C-mol%, as shown in Fig. 4 and Table S1. The yield of the HDO products increased in the following order; 1,2-BuD (1.37 C-mol%) > 1,2,4-BuT (1.11 C-mol%) > 2,3-BuD (0.17 C-mol%) > 1,4-BuD (0.03 C-mol%). The HDO products mainly possessed vicinal hydroxyl groups. The other HDO products, 1,2-propandiol (1,2-PrD), CO2, ethylene glycol, monoalcohol, and alkanes were concomitantly generated at small yields. Cyclic product via dehydration including 1,4-anhydroerythritol was not detected. Additionally, the carbon recovery for Cu/C was almost 100 %, indicating that the oligomerized products and highly oxygenated compounds which could not be detected by GC were not produced. Therefore, the Cu/C prepared in this study was able to remove part of the hydroxyl groups with high selectivity. The HDO reaction mechanism over Cu/C is discussed in Section 3.3. In contrast, using Cu/AC as the catalyst, the erythritol conversion was only 0.20 C-mol% and the main product was CO2. The low activity of Cu/AC was ascribed to the small amount of metal active sites, as measured by N2O titration. Though small Cu particles in Cu/AC were observed by TEM measurement, Cu/AC had little metal surface area measured by N2O titration. This could be possibly because of impurities in AC which had strong interaction with Cu to form less reducible Cu small particles. The erythritol conversion over Cu/SiO2 was comparable to that of Cu/C and BuDs and BuTs were mainly obtained for these two catalysts. The carbon recovery for Cu/SiO2 was 79 C-mol%, implying that the formation of undetectable compounds by GC, such as the oligomers of erythritol and highly oxygenated compounds. The conversion of erythritol over Cu chromite was small. Therefore, the prepared Cu/C exhibited the high HDO activity. Additionally, the stability of Cu was determined by characterizing the spent catalyst. The XRD patterns of the fresh and spent catalysts are shown in Fig. 2. Although small diffraction peaks corresponding to Cu2O were observed in the spent Cu/C, the Cu metallic state and particle size were maintained throughout the reaction for most of the Cu particles in Cu/C. Moreover, Cu2O was formed by the oxidation of Cu during the reaction and/or the catalyst recovery process in which the catalyst was exposed to air. The Cu particle size of the spent Cu/C observed by TEM was almost comparable to that of the fresh Cu/C. Thus, small Cu particles in Cu/C were successfully maintained throughout the HDO reaction. In the case of Cu/AC, the Cu particle size of the spent catalyst increased from 22.7 to 30.7 nm, indicating that further agglomeration occurred during the reaction. For Cu/SiO2 and Cu chromite, the intensity of the diffraction peaks of the spent catalyst became smaller than those of the fresh catalysts, suggesting that the crystallinity of Cu decreased during the erythritol conversion. This could be because that the surface Cu atoms moved on the catalyst supports during the reaction. Therefore, Cu/C catalyst realized high activity of HDO and high stability of Cu nanoparticles. It is commonly accepted that both small metal particle sizes and high metal loadings increase the possibility of agglomeration. However, small Cu sizes were maintained with high Cu loading of the Cu/C catalyst. The difference in the sintering resistance of Cu between Cu/C and other catalysts was attributed to the confinement structure of Cu/C, where the Cu particles were immobilized in the carbon support, as discussed in Section 3.1. Additionally, the reusability test was conducted to elucidate the stability of Cu/C catalyst. The recovered catalyst after erythritol HDO was dried overnight at room temperature and reduced in the same manner as the pretreatment for the fresh catalyst. The second erythritol HDO was performed at the same reaction condition, at catalyst loading of 0.04 gCu/gerythritol and 180 °C under 1.8 MPa H2 for 24 h. As shown in Table S2, high activity and product selectivities were maintained in the second use, suggesting that the active site for HDO in Cu/C did not change during the reaction, recovery, and regeneration procedures. The prepared Cu/C demonstrated high activity for the HDO of erythritol, and higher stability and carbon recovery than other Cu catalysts prepared with different supports, which could make the determination of the reaction mechanism easier and more precise. Therefore, we hereafter selected the Cu/C catalyst for the further investigation of HDO of erythritol. 3.2.2 Effect of reaction temperature and reaction time on erythritol HDO over Cu/C The HDO of erythritol over Cu/C produced not only BuDs but also BuTs and C1–C3 products. The HDO reactions can proceed in series and the HDO products can participate in cracking reactions. Therefore, the reaction temperature and reaction time are key parameters affecting the HDO yield. To investigate the effects temperature and reaction time on erythritol conversion and product selectivity, the HDO of erythritol over Cu/C was carried out at 150, 165, and 180 °C, and the reaction time was systematically varied from 24 to 240 h. The amount of catalyst in the reactor was set at 0.2 gCu/gerythritol and the initial H2 pressure was fixed at 1.8 MPa. As shown in Fig. 5 (a) and Table S3, increasing the reaction temperature and reaction time significantly increased the conversion of erythritol. The erythritol conversions at 150, 165, and 180 °C were respectively 1.9, 7.3, and 16.3 C-mol% at 120 h and 5.3, 14.9, and 33.8 C-mol% at 240 h. The HDO product selectivity was almost constant with time at each reaction temperature, suggesting that HDO and the cracking reactions proceeded in parallel. The HDO product selectivity increased with a decrease in the reaction temperature, indicating that the activation energy of the HDO reaction was smaller than that of the CC bond cleavage reaction and that the HDO reaction was favored at lower reaction temperatures. The relationship between reaction temperature and selectivity was in good agreement with the previously reported results for glycerol HDO over other Cu catalysts [28,44]. The TOF values were ranged from 0.08–1.7 h−1 and increased with the reaction temperature. The TOF value of erythritol HDO at catalyst loading of 0.2 gCu/gerythritol and 180 °C for 24 h (1.7 h−1) was smaller than that at catalyst loading of 0.2 gCu/gerythritol and same reaction temperature and time (4.0 h−1). This difference in the TOF value could be because the diffusion resistance of the reactants to Cu surface of Cu/C affected the reaction rate. The most part of Cu metal of Cu/C was inside the micropores and the reactants could access Cu surface from bulk aqueous phase via small pores slowly. Focusing on the selectivity of the HDO products, BuD selectivity increased with reaction time, whereas BuT selectivity was almost constant at erythritol conversions above 20 C-mol%, as shown in Fig. 5(b). Butanols and butane were produced with low yields as shown in Table S3. These results indicated that the HDO of erythritol to BuT and HDO of BuT to BuD proceeded sequentially, while further HDO of BuD to butanol hardly proceeded, which was attributed to the reaction mechanism of HDO, as discussed in Section 3.3. We finally achieved 18.3 C-mol% BuD yield from erythritol over Cu/C catalyst at 180 °C and 1.8 MPa H2 for 240 h. The prepared Cu/C catalyst exhibited high BuD selectivity (> 40 C-mol%) for all reaction conditions, which was ascribed to the smaller metal particle size of Cu and the inert carbon support (absence of active sites for side reactions). The obtained BuD selectivity was higher than that reported in the literature using Cu based catalyst (, 38.6 C-mol% for Cu/CaO-Al2O3, reaction temperature 230 °C, and hydrogen pressure at 2.8 MPa [12]), which could be because of the use of inert carbon support. On the other hand, the obtained 1,2-butanediol (16.2 C-mol%) was still lower than that obtained by using ReOx-Pd/CeO2 catalyst and 1,4-dioxane solvent (77 C-mol% [10]) and further optimization of the reaction condition and improvement of Cu/C catalyst to accelerate the access of the reactants to Cu surface are needed. 3.2.3 Effect of hydrogen pressure on erythritol HDO over Cu/C Because the HDO of erythritol was carried out in a batch reactor, the hydrogen pressure widely changed with reaction time, as shown in Fig. S3. To understand the reaction pathway of erythritol HDO, the effect of H2 pressure must be determined. Thus, the effect of initial hydrogen pressure on the product yield and selectivity for the erythritol HDO reaction over Cu/C was investigated. The hydrogen pressure was varied from 0.3 to 1.8 MPa, and the selected ratio of the amount of metal in the catalyst to the amount of the reactant was 0.2 gCu/gerythritol. For all the experiments, the hydrogen gas remained after 24 h reaction; hence, the erythritol reaction proceeded throughout the reaction period. As shown in Fig. 6 and Table S3, the erythritol conversion and the yield of HDO product were 14.2 C-mol% and 9.3 C-mol%, respectively, at an initial pressure of 0.3 MPa and 9.2 C-mol% and 6.0 C-mol% at H2 pressures above 0.9 MPa. The slight decrease in the erythritol conversion with H2 pressure was attributed to the competitive adsorption of erythritol and hydrogen, which is consistent with the literature [14]. For Cu catalysts using support possessing solid acid sites, hydroxyl group in erythritol and hydrogen are likely to be adsorbed on the solid acid and Cu metal. Therefore, the competitive adsorption of H2 and the reactant was not generally observed [12,28,45]. Conversely, the prepared Cu/C catalyst did not possess solid acid site and erythritol adsorbed on Cu surface was involved in the reaction. Therefore, the competitive adsorption of H2 and erythritol could be observed for Cu/C. However, as the hydrogen pressure decreased to 0.74 MPa during erythritol HDO over Cu/C at 180 °C for 240 h (Fig. S3), the effect of H2 pressure on the erythritol conversion and HDO yield was limited for the HDO reaction tested in the previous section. Moreover, the HDO product selectivity was almost constant (65–68 C-mol%) with H2 pressure, suggesting that HDO and the cracking reactions proceeded in parallel. Therefore, the effect of H2 pressure on the erythritol conversion was almost negligible under the reaction conditions tested (0.7–1.8 MPa); therefore, the reaction pathway could be discussed based on the change in product yield with reaction time. 3.3 Insight into the erythritol HDO pathway and mechanism over Cu/C To gain a deeper understanding of the erythritol conversion over the Cu/C catalyst, an investigation of the reaction pathway and mechanism was undertaken. Focusing on the HDO reaction of erythritol to BuDs, the reaction proceeded in series via BuTs. To elucidate the successive HDO reactions, the yields of BuTs and BuDs were plotted against erythritol conversion. As shown in Fig. 5(b), the yield of BuTs increased with an increase in the erythritol conversion up to 15 C-mol% and then slightly decreased. In contrast, the BuD yield monotonically increased with erythritol conversion. These trends in the yield against the conversion were generally observed in series reactions where erythritol was first converted to BuTs as an intermediate and BuTs were further converted to BuDs as the final product. Only a small amount of butanol was obtained during the erythritol conversion at 180 °C and 1.2 MPa H2 for 240 h, suggesting that BuDs were stable under the reaction conditions tested over Cu/C; therefore, BuDs behaved as the final product of the successive HDO of erythritol. Next, the detailed HDO reaction network of erythritol over Cu/C was investigated. As shown in Fig. 5(a), three types of BuDs, 1,2-BuD, 2,3-BuD, and 1,4-BuD were produced during the HDO of erythritol. To elucidate which reaction pathway mainly proceeded to form BuDs in erythritol HDO over Cu/C, HDO reactions of 1,2,4-BuT and 1,2,3-BuT were carried out over Cu/C at 180 °C and 1.8 MPa H2 for 24 h. As shown in Table S5 and Fig. 7 , the conversions reached approximately 10 C-mol% for erythritol, 1,2,3-BuT, and 1,2,4-BuT after 24 h. 1,2-BuD and 1,4-BuD were mainly obtained from 1,2,4-BuT, and 1,2-BuD and 2,3-BuD were mainly obtained from 1,2,3-BuT. The formation of 1,3-BuD was not observed with either reactant. The presence of 2,3-BuD in erythritol HDO indicates the formation of 1,2,3-BuT as an intermediate, although it was not detected. Therefore, the amount of 1,2,3-BuT produced from erythritol was likely small, and 1,2,3-BuT was almost completely converted to BuDs in the HDO of erythritol. The selectivity of 2,3-BuD (5.0 C-mol%) from erythritol was smaller than that from 1,2,3-BuT (16.3 C-mol%). Therefore, the formation of 1,2,4-BuT was more likely than 1,2,3-BuT from erythritol over Cu/C. Because 1,2-BuD was formed with high selectivity (54.1 C-mol%) from 1,2,4-BuT, 1,2-BuD was the main BuD product from erythritol. Additionally, the HDO of glycerol and 1,2-PrD was performed under the same condition as that of BuTs. 1,2-PrD was selectively produced from glycerol. Dehydrated compounds, such as hydroxyacetone and 3-hydroxypropanal, were not observed in the HDO of glycerol. The HDO of 1,2-PrD slightly proceeded over Cu/C. Due to the similarity in the products obtained from erythritol and glycerol, the HDO of these polyols could proceed via same reaction mechanism. The high conversion of glycerol was attributed to the smaller molecule size of glycerol which could more easily access the Cu surface. In summary, the HDO reaction network is illustrated in Fig. 8 . The main HDO reaction of erythritol over Cu/C was the production of 1,2-BuD via 1,2,4-BuT. As reaction network was confirmed, the HDO reaction mechanism was finally investigated. Most of the HDO products from erythritol and glycerol over Cu/C possessed vicinal hydroxyl groups, except for 1,4-BuD, and the HDO of diols seldom proceeded. The HDO of polyols are generally explained by the dehydration-hydrogenation mechanism and the dehydrogenation-dehydration-hydrogenation mechanism [16,26,46]. These reaction mechanisms can explain that the formation of 1,2,4-BuT is more likely to occur as the protonated intermediate of 1,2,4-BuT is more stable and likely to form than that of 1,2,3-BuT. However, the dehydration of polyol in these mechanisms undergoes on the solid acid sites. Therefore, these mechanisms are not suitable to explain the HDO mechanism of Cu/C which does not possess solid acid sites. Additionally, these mechanisms cannot explain the selective production of 1,2-BuD from 1,2,4-BuT. From these considerations, we envisaged that the vicinal hydroxyl groups in erythritol were involved in a stable adsorption state on the Cu surface, and the HDO reaction proceeded between the hydroxyl groups that were not involved in the adsorption and the hydrogen atoms on the Cu metal surface. A similar reaction pathway was proposed by Kühne et al. [32] for the HDO of mannitol over Raney Cu in which the main products were haxanetriols and hexanetetraols possessing terminal vicinal hydroxyl groups. The following HDO reaction mechanism was concluded: Two adjacent hydroxyl groups in the reactant were adsorbed on the Cu metal surface to form a stable adsorption state, and the hydroxyl groups that were not involved in the adsorption reacted with the hydrogen atoms on the Cu surface. In this mechanism, neither HDO nor cracking of the hydroxyl groups involved in the adsorption on the Cu surface proceeded. Although a detailed investigation is still necessary to confirm the reaction mechanism of the HDO over the prepared Cu/C, we considered that the mechanism reported by Khüne et al. could be applied to our reaction because of the similarities in the reactants and catalysts. The difference in selectivity between 1,2,3-BuT and 1,2,4-BuT was likely due to the proximity between the hydroxyl groups adsorbed on the Cu surface and those involved in the HDO reaction. Because of the small pore size of the prepared Cu/C, the terminal vicinal hydroxyl groups were able to access the Cu metal surface more easily than the internal vicinal hydroxyl groups. Therefore, the reaction between the hydroxyl groups adjacent to those adsorbed on the Cu metal surface and the hydrogen atoms was more likely, resulting in a higher selectivity for 1,2,4-BuT from erythritol than that for 1,2,3-BuT. Similarly, the selectivity for 1,2-BuD was greater than that for 2,3-BuD because of the higher accessibility of the terminal vicinal hydroxyl groups compared with that of the internal hydroxyl groups. From 1,2,4-BuT, 1,2-BuD was selectively formed because the adsorption state of 1,2,4-BuT was limited to the 1- and 2-hydroxyl groups on adjacent positions. The further HDO of 1,2-BuD hardly proceeded because 1,2-BuD did not possess the hydroxyl groups which were not involved in the stable adsorption state. In addition to the desired HDO products, 1,2-PrD, CO2, and a small amount of glycerol were obtained as the by-products of erythritol conversion, suggesting that cleavage of the terminal CC bond of erythritol proceeded. 1,2-PrD was formed from 1,2,3-BuT with concomitant formation of CO2 and from glycerol, whereas almost no cracking products were obtained from 1,2,4-BuT. These results suggest that 1,2-PrD can be obtained by HDO and the decarbonization of the terminal COH moiety of erythritol via 1,2,3-BuT or glycerol. Although the difference between the active sites for HDO and CC cleavage has not been completely elucidated, one of the possible differences is the Cu surface coordination; the Cu atoms on unsaturated coordination sites (edge, step, and corner) are considered to exhibit Lewis acidity. Hence, we envisaged that the HDO reaction proceeded on the Cu plane surface, while CC cleavage proceeded on the edge sites of the Cu surface [47,48]. 4 Conclusion For the selective HDO of biomass-derived polyols into useful chemicals at low hydrogen pressures, a carbon-supported Cu nanoparticle catalyst was prepared using an ion-exchange resin as the carbon material. The Cu/C catalyst possessed fine Cu particles (d TEM = 14.9 nm), and high Cu loading (66.9 wt%) was successfully prepared by this method. The erythritol HDO activity of Cu/C was comparable to that of Cu/SiO2 and significantly higher than Cu/AC and Cu chromite at 180 °C and 1.8 MPa H2. The size of Cu particles in Cu/C was maintained after the HDO reaction while the agglomeration of Cu particles was observed for Cu/AC and the decrease of Cu crystallinity was observed for Cu/SiO2 and Cu chromite. The high activity and stability of Cu/C was because of the large Cu metal surface area and high hydrothermal stability, which was likely due to the Cu metal particles embedded in the carbon support. The effects of reaction conditions on the HDO of erythritol over Cu/C were investigated. The HDO selectivity increased with a decrease in the reaction temperature, whereas the selectivity for BuDs in the HDO products decreased. The higher HDO selectivity at lower reaction temperatures was ascribed to the smaller activation energy of the HDO reaction compared with that of the CC bond cleavage reaction. The slight decrease of erythritol conversion was observed with increase of H2 pressure, suggesting that the competitive adsorption of H2 and erythritol on the Cu surface. While the effect of H2 pressure on the product selectivity was almost negligible. The highest BuD yield of 18.3 C-mol% was realized for the erythritol conversion over the Cu/C catalyst at 180 °C and 1.8 MPa H2 for 240 h. Additionally, the reaction pathway of HDO of erythritol was examined. In the HDO of erythritol over Cu/C, 1,2-BuD was obtained with the highest yield, which was produced by a sequential HDO via 1,2,4-BuT. The BuDs with vicinal hydroxyl groups were favorably formed over the prepared Cu/C because the vicinal hydroxyl groups in the reactant were adsorbed on the Cu plain surface to form a stable adsorption state, and cleavage of the closest CO bond was more likely to occur, as reported in the literature [12]. coredata.dc:description: For the selective hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of erythritol to butanediols, a carbon-supported Cu catalyst (Cu/C) with small copper particles (diameter of 14.9 nm) at high metal loading (66.9 wt%) was prepared using a weakly acidic cation-exchange resin as the carbon support precursor. Compared with the activated carbon-supported Cu catalyst prepared by the impregnation method, Cu/C showed high activity, high butanediol selectivity, and high sintering resistance. The effects of reaction temperature, reaction time, and initial hydrogen pressure on erythritol conversion and butanediol selectivity were also studied. The highest butanediol yield of 18.3 C-mol% at a butanediol selectivity of 54 C-mol% was realized over the Cu/C catalyst at 180 °C and 1.8 MPa H2 for 240 h. Moreover, the HDO of erythritol to butanediols over Cu/C proceeded mainly via 1,2,4-butanetriol. Vicinal diols such as 1,2-butanediol and 2,3-butanediol were favorably formed over the Cu surface because the substrates were adsorbed on Cu via the two vicinal OH groups and these OH groups did not participate in the HDO reactions.
coredata.dc:title: Selective aqueous phase hydrodeoxygenation of erythritol over carbon-supported Cu catalyst prepared from ion-exchange resin
